description: Uncertain, first attested as teachie in the 1597 first quarto versions of Romeo and Juliet and Richard III. Perhaps coined by Shakespeare. Also variously derived from English tetch (â€œtantrum, fit of angerâ€); from Scots tache (â€œblotch, faultâ€); from Middle English tatch (â€œblemishâ€) &c. under influence from touchy, in turn derived from Old French tache, from proposed Vulgar Latin *tacca, from Gothic ğ„ğŒ°ğŒ¹ğŒºğŒ½ğƒ (taikns, â€œsignâ€), from proposed Proto-Indo-European *deyá¸±-.

entries.meaning: Synonym of touchy: easily annoyed or irritated, peevish, testy, irascible; also (figurative) extremely sensitive, difficult to manage, use, or work.
